												It's important to note that this review is based off the PC version of the game.Sometimes an App needs to just stay out of the PC market, and stay as an App. This is the only thing I could think of during my time with Ratventure Challenge. The games genre is a simple one, build a bridge and get object A to point B. There are many of this type of these games in the genre, I haven't really played many of them. Names like Bridge Constructor, World of Goo, etc, jump to mind, just to name a few. The genre has never really garnered much interest in me, it always seemed rather repetitive. With Ratventure Challenge, I thought it would be a nice, interesting, way to break myself into the genre.For the most part it does the job. The physics of the game can be a little strange and the game has some very odd design decisions, all of which we will be discussing here in this review. So lets start with something obvious. If you noticed at the top of this article, many prices are listed, ranging from five bucks to two bucks. Normally I don't list prices of the game on my blog, because I feel monetary value of a game is different from person to person. However in this case, I wanted to use them as a object point to a particular issue I have with this title. There is NO difference between the three versions of the game. Why is there a price difference? Simply for the pleasure of playing that game on that particular device? Now, I could ramble on about how this all seems shady but I will leave it at that for now.Straight from when you launch the game, Ratventure screams App. There isn't any retooling of options, buttons, or even the way you can interact with the screen. There are absolutely no graphics control or option menus present whatsoever. All you're left with is a sound off/on, music off/on button.The game also is stuck in 1280/720 resolution, if you wanted to play it on full screen, there is no in-game way of doing this currently. For a PC port this is rather disappointing in most regards.Now let's get to the good stuff, the game play. Now if you were to ask me simply, is the game fun? I would say yes, ignoring all the other issues the game has a whole. The game is simple enough to play, with you building small pieces in a massive wooden structure, in hopes of getting some delicious cheese. The puzzles vary in difficulty and sometimes not in order. One level is ridiculously hard and then the next will be rather easy. I think this issue has to do with the fact that Ratventure doesn't really evolve all too much as a game. There are buzz-saws and rope hooks to change things up occasionally, but for the most part your building pieces never evolve or change.Level designs are varied enough as you progress deeper into the games 72 levels and some of them can be quite the brain tickler. To help you along is a handy hint button that does a fairly good job of showing how to do it in the 3 star requirement. However, it doesn't let you do it step by step more then it shows it all at once and expects you to remember, this is probably done on purpose as it would be too easy otherwise. The game also features a useful "Undo last action button" that doesn't really work at all. The button only lets you undo the last action and sometimes not at all depending on what happens in the game. The game is full of these strange little inconveniences. As an example, if either of the rats die by some means, either falling or buzz-saw, you have to rebuild your entire structure over again, instead of just simply hitting the undo button.Why have this button at all?Designing structures isn't too difficult. The game does respond quite rapidly to commands and the structure dynamically responds to the changes you make. If one side of the structure is built upon too much, it begins to sag or bend. If the rats jump on the structure, the structure responds to the sudden shift in weight. Keeping the aforementioned effects in mind, works rather well and lets you plan out your moves quite effectively. One thing that did annoy me quite a bit about the game though, was the fact that the rats won't go after the cheese even if it's in their faces. You have got to build the structure on top of the cheese and move them to it. The rats are stupid, and won't walk on grass.Aesthetically speaking, Ratventure is just fine. The levels mostly change in color and the backdrop. Ratventure isn't certainly the most pretty of games but it isn't the ugliest as well, it gets the job done. I would have enjoyed a little bit of personality injected into the game. When the rats hit the buzz-saws they simply just fall off the screen. There could've been some added humor with them being ripped to bits or a funny sound effect. The game is just very monotone from beginning to end. Musically I felt the same about the game, while it never became grating on my ears, I never really noticed it or felt it was pleasant.There is no story nor sense of personality to this game. You just hit the play button and that is simply it. No little cut scenes or images to explain anything. The game does offer a fair bit of replay value in chasing down the mystical 3 star achievement. There really isn't much of a reason to do this, no rewards or anything unlocked other then steam achievements, you just did it. Congratulations.So you may be thinking I am coming off a bit harsh on this game? Keep in mind this was on the PC. I hold my PC games to a higher degree/standard and demand a bit more out of them. App games have the right to be simple on their platform, given the limitations of that platform. I would've probably been more than okay with all the issues and aspects to the game, had I played it on my phone or pad. However, the developer felt the need to make this PC port that is uninspiring and not very well done. Is the game fun? Yes. But is it worth it on PC? No. Get this game on your phone or pad, it's cheaper and you will probably enjoy it more as something to pass the time at the DMV.I only recommend this title, if its on sale, you really love bridge construction games, and know what you're getting. Otherwise buy it on your phone only!

												What do you get when you take elements of Transformice, World of Goo, and Poly Bridge (all of which being far better than this), throw them in a blender, and hit liquify? What you should have is a big mess, and that's exactly what you get with Tiny Bridge: Ratventure.First off, this is quite obviously a mobile port. I was first suspicious from the startup resolution, which is locked at 1280x768. A 16:10 resolution, and a failry odd one at that. "Any options to change it or go fullscreen?" You're kidding right? The options are almost non-existent, with your only real options being turning the sounds and music on or off. Not up or down, on or off. There's also a button on the main menu that gives a bare-bones tutorial, but we'll get to gameplay in a bit.Your goal is to get your two mice to collect the glowing cheeses by making a bridge, and using as few pieces as possible to do it. One interesting thing I will give this game is that you're supposed to use your mice as counterweights to help balance the bridge in question. "Wait, aren't bridges supposed to be stable?" Nevermind that for now! But yes. Sounds cool, right? You get to not only guide your mice to their goal, but make them be PART of the puzzle? Indeed, it does… it SOUNDS cool. Then you play it. And where do I even begin with the gameplay?First, if you want a three-star, perfect level, there's literally only one way to do it: the way the hint button tell you to, and verbatum at that. If you deviate by any considerable margin or try to do it your own way, you won't get the perfect finish. Even if you collect all the optional cheeses and use less than half the parts given to you, you'll likely only get two stars, max. The hint button also makes the leaderboards moot, as everyone can just use the hints to achieve the perfect score (and many of the achievments if they have the patience).Speaking of collection, there's a serious problem with hitboxes. Just look up screencaps of this game and you'll see that sometimes the mice will literally be touching the cheese but will refuse to collect it. "Just reach out and grab it, you lazy cusses! D=<" No, they have to be directly on top of it for it to count, and getting them to do that is a lot harder than it sounds.While on the subject of lazy mice, sometimes the tall thin one will refuse to move along with the short fat one, making me wonder if there's something wrong with me or if it's the game. Has anyone else had this problem, and if so, how do I fix it?Then there's the physics. Yeeeeeeaaaaaaaaaaaaahhhh, they're not good, which is a real bad thing considering this is a bridge building game at heart. They're inconsistent, so much so that I've done the same thing several times in the same level and gotten different results. Tiny Bridge, you are not Bad Rats. Don't be like that.To summarize, do you remember those three games I listed up at the top of the review? Play those instead. Yes, even Transformice.

												Tiny Bridge: Ratventure is basically a bridge building game with an active element where you need to move the two rats and gather the cheese pieces as the structure you built swing and stretch based on the weight. It is a puzzle game that has been done before, but usually, the units (lemmings, monkeys, etc.) move on their own logic toward the exit, rather than you controlling it. The idea is to use minimum number of moves and minimum number of segments to build the structure. This is obviously a mobile game port, as the structure is identical to many similar action-puzzle games, including the long-lived Angry Birds franchise, where you have multiple "stages", each stage containing a dozen or more levels and you can get up to 3 stars per level. The more stars, the more levels are unlocked. There's not much else to the game though. The trick is in how complicated structure you have to build and how to minimize the steps you have to take to grab all the cheese. As the cheese are further apart and terrain gets trickier, the structures you build start to take on Rube Goldberg machine properties even though they aren't supposed to move... much. If you want a bridge-building game, there are better ones. This is a puzzle game similar to Worlds of Goo where you build structures to reach stuff. It's really nothing special.

Full Disclosure: Copy supplied by the developer for review.What happens when you take World of Goo and combine it with Bridge Builder?! Well, you get Tiny Bridge Ratventure. The basic premise of the game is to traverse 2 rats through a hostile terrain by building structures to collect cheese. The main principal of this physics basic bridge builder is nothing new as there are a lot of these type of games on the market but Ratventure does offer a few different mechanics that set it asside from the rest. Regardless of Ratventures small amount originalities, they still do not justify a $10.99 price point. My recommendation is only to buy it on sale (like $.21).Lets look at the good (pro's), the bad (con's), and the ugly (straight-up "no no's"). The Good (Pro's) is that I am partial to these physics based bridge builder type games. The developer Estelion added player semi-controlled mechanics (opposed to automated as most bridge builder games are but movement is limited to points on the structure) making traversing the structure a little more difficult with hazards on the map. To add to the difficulty, they've added bonus cheese for extra points in addition to the level ending big cheese. The non-player controlled mechanics (I want to call these sprites "enemies" but they both help and hinder progress, so we will label them as "NPC's") have both positive and negative affects on your structure, sometimes making it bounce and sway, or adding stability to a structure. Building on to your structure while while its swaying all over the screen adds a challenge as well as a lot more teadium to the time it takes to build. Though you are limited to only building strut parts to your structure, in addition to the NPC's there are added variables for your bridge in the maps. These include ancor points and rope suspenders, both of which you have little to no placement control over.  The Bad (Con's) is that there are a lot of these games to choose from. Most of which at the same price point (not on sale) offer better graphics, better sound, more gameplay options or are just cheaper. Next, the only instruction for the game is pictures... Yes, there is not one word written for this game. Though it easy is to pick up, you still have to figure out how to play this game through the cryptic picture instructions given to you at the begining; and even then, there is no explanation of what everything does. Regardless, there is always trial and error or the community hub... Good luck there! I have not confirmed this but it is apparent with the game play that Ratventure is likely ported from either Andriod or iOS formats (couldn't find this one on the Google market) the bad part about it is that the games porting was never updated for the PC. This becomes more apparent with the instructions telling you to use your finger with the game mechanics. The Ugly (straight-up "no no's") part of the bad is that while the graphics are only okay, there are 6 worlds, each are just reskinned repeats of the last, and they never offer additional mechanics to differenciate it from it from the others. The first bit of ugliness most will notice is the lack of menu options. The only options that are available are play, a link to the dev's website, instructions (or lack there-of), and mute - which is not a bad thing as both the sound and music are absolutely horendous. Make sure you have a decent playlist ready before you start playing. Lastly with the options (again... or lack there-of), there is no full screen (...or any other graphic options for that matter), no control options, not even an exit... wow. Estelion developers please note this article on The Ten Commandments of Video Game Menu's.OverviewGameplay: Physics based Logic Builder  
Graphics: Lacking but otherwise okay.
Sound: OMG! MAKE IT STOP!
Controls: Better on a touch screen. Mouse controls for everyone else. 
Replayability: Though I have yet to figure out how to get anything more than one star on a level, the challenge for more stars is offered. I'd think most people will never play a level again once it has been passed.
Overall: Good for a couple hours and is a fun game if you are into the gameplay, otherwise it may not be worth your time and money.
The verdict for gamers is to avoid it if your not into the gameplay and buy it on sale!

Tiny Bridge: AchievementureNote: I've idled for cards for 4,8 hours. My actual playtime is high for reasons. Find out below. I also got the game for 20-ish cents, if I remember correctly.Benefits :◆Plenty of levels.◆Undo 1 move button.◆Zoom-in and zoom-out options.◆Trading cards.◆Achievements.Drawbacks :◆No fullscreen option. Alt + enter won't work either.◆There are some bugs. When you undo a move sometimes the construction you've build would move (literally), resulting in planks getting cut or in a death. Either way you have to restart the level.◆Another well-know bug is when you build a diagonal bridge and when it's close to falling but not that close planks go bananas, the construction is rotating and you have to retry the level.◆The price seems a bit high, in my opinion as the game is not perfect and for 10 euros one would probably expect more.◆The game crashed at least once.◆Frogs dying when they see a construction moving close to them. Wtf?◆Some of the levels require you to place planks exactly as shown in the hint video making the game extremely difficult. I knew what I needed to do and I still spent at least 4 hours trying to complete a single level. That's anything but normal given the fact that it could be finished in 3-4 mins... Also I haven't completed that level yet and I am not sure if I will be able to do so at all, sadly.Conclusion :I had some fun playing the game, but I raged and was frustrated too. Mostly the latter. Avoid at all costs. Worse than Bad Rats even. Why? Because someone had spent a week trying to complete a single level to no avail. Other - 12 hours on a level that they did finish at least. And I have been stuck on one for 4+ hours. It's funny because these levels can be completed in a couple minutes or so. This game is simply not worth your time.Try Harder Simulator

Game: Ratventure ChallengeGenre: Dynamic Bridge BuilderDeveloper: EstelionPublisher: EstelionCopy supplied by developerRatventure Challenge is the port of an iOS puzzle game (or "dynamic bridge builder" as the creators like to call it) developed and published by Estelion. It's about a couple of rats who want an unlimited amount of cheese, and that's what they do for the entire game.GRAPHICSThe characters and background don't look bad or anything, but the repetitive levels and poor animations show the game's nature as mobile game port.GAMEPLAYYour goal is to reach the big piece of cheese at the other end of the level, while trying to use less pieces of wood for your bridge as possible, as well as collecting as many pieces of cheese as possible to get an higher score at the end of level. Either I am really bad at this game, or there is something wrong with the physics. Most of the time, you will feel really frustrated by the unintuitive gameplay. There is a hint system which tells you exactly what to do to beat a level, but having to alternate between constructing and moving the rats doesn't make things easier and show that not much love was put into the port.CHALLENGEThe game doesn't feel challenging, but frustrating. The physics are illogical, the level design is not all that great and there is no learning curve: you'll find yourself going from an easy level to an hard one to an easy one again in a matter of seconds.SOUNDRepetitive music? Check. Poor amount of sound effects? Double check. Music not playing randomly? TRIPLE CHECK.REPLAYABILITYOther than trying to get an high-score in each of the 72 levels, there aren't secrets or unlockables that will make you come back to this game.This game is not for me, mostly because of its obvious nature as an iOS port and the terrible physics. The game is relatively cheap, and if you like this genre then you will love this and have a good time. 												When I originally bought this, I was looking forward to playing this. It was alright for the first 5 - 10 levels, but then it became dull and boring for me. However, this is just my personal preference. Pros: - Game is rather simple.  - The physics are okay.Cons:  - Redundant gameplay. Feels like you are playing the same levels over and over. - "Building" the bridge is VERY limited to what you can do.  - Game play overall feels a lot like Angry Birds; try and get 3 stars on every level to unlock more levels. - The background music doesn't really help the "fun" factor. It's cute, but hearing the same thing loop over and over gets old fast.Again, everyone has their own opinion. This is just mine.

												If world of goo is using dynamic stuctures to find static solutions, TBR is using static structures to find dynamic solutions. All but the earliest levels will rely on your bridge bending, breaking, or falling off a cliff to solve the puzzle. It's a neat idea, but between the interface, the sound design and the infuriating piece placement I can't bring myself to reccomend it. It all becomes a chore far too quickly.Steam really needs a "meh" review option, but in lieu of than it's getting a thumbs down.
